snp3.3:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
snp3.3:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
snp3.3:2.1: “Mendicants, speech that has four factors is well spoken, not poorly spoken. It’s blameless and is not criticized by sensible people.
snp3.3:2.3: It’s when a mendicant speaks well, not poorly; they speak on the teaching, not against the teaching; they speak pleasantly, not unpleasantly; and they speak truthfully, not falsely.
snp3.3:2.4: Speech with these four factors is well spoken, not poorly spoken. It’s blameless and is not criticized by sensible people.”
snp3.3:2.5: That is what the Buddha said.
snp3.3:2.6: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
snp3.3:3.1: “Good people say that well-spoken words are foremost;
snp3.3:3.2: second, speak on the teaching, not against it;
snp3.3:3.4: and fourth, speak truthfully, not falsely.”
snp3.3:4.1: Then Venerable Vaṅgīsa got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said,
snp3.3:4.2: “I feel inspired to speak, Blessed One! I feel inspired to speak, Holy One!”
snp3.3:4.3: “Then speak as you feel inspired,” said the Buddha.
snp3.3:4.4: Then Vaṅgīsa extolled the Buddha in his presence with fitting verses:
